Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2015 01:19AM RebzAmy wrote: I know somebody who had a 98% chance of survival and she had hormonal breast cancer and was on Letrozole for 5 years. She came off them and 2 years later was diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer, which probably meant that she was possibly stage 4 from the start but that the Letrozole was holding it in check until she came off it. So, some of the 93% go on to develop secondaries - that's what I think I understand the question to be.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 05:10PM RebzAmy wrote: As a new wife and stepmother myself to an 11 year old boy, your posts really struck a cord with me. I made a really big effort to include my stepson's late mother in our lives. He has a memory box, some photos of his late mother on his bedroom wall, various other things in his room which were hers and I made it clear that his late mother is part of all of our lives and always will be. Occasionally he gets upset about his mummy (he was 6 when she passed) and we deal with it. I will always  make sure the memories are preserved. I've also developed a special relationship with my stepson's grandparents who treat me like a daughter-in-law - it's a very special relationship all round.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 04:50AM RebzAmy wrote: Hi Kmtmom1 A large number of lumps that are found by women are in fact benign. It is important to be breast aware and gets lumps checked out so the best thing you could do is go and get that MRI you were supposed to have. I know it's easy for me to say this as you're probably scared due to your mum's diagnosis at a young age but the sooner the better and hopefully it will just be  still fibrocystic changes. Nobody here can tell you what it is which is why you should just make the appointment. If it helps at all, my mum had a huge lump in her breast and was told it was most likely BC but it in fact turned out to be a huge fluid filled cyst or something like that. The good thing is that you only had a scan relatively recently so please go and get the follow up you were supposed to get.  RebzAmy

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2016 04:23AM RebzAmy wrote: I have taken amitriptyline for years (since 2007 when I was diagnosed with breast cancer). I started taking a very low dose 10-20mg to help me sleep at night and take the edge off my anxiety whilst I was being diagnosed and going through treatment and it was great. I continued taking it until recently when I decided to wean myself off it. Within a very short space of time, I started feeling really unwell, pain in my neck, shoulders and especially jaw (always suffered from jaw pain and headaches) and was having headaches at night and during the day that I couldn't shift and nausea and just aching, I also wear a nightguard on my teeth as I clench my teeth at night. Went to dentist and told him about my painful jaw and neck - got referred to hospital and had MRI scans which showed severe arthritis in my jaw and neck. Was told that amitriptyline is a drug they would prescribe for this sort of pain. Put myself back on it immediately and the relief from the pain and feeling ill was noticeable the next day and by the day after I felt back to myself again. It so does work for pain. My husband takes it for his MS pain. I only take it at night as it makes you a bit sleepy but I get a good night's sleep with it. I'm having jaw surgery and injections into all the painful areas in a few weeks time.
Posts.Title: Is anyone taking Amitriptyline for pain? Louisap Soniatoronto

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 03:02AM RebzAmy wrote: Hi Nora and Fightinhrd I had a breast reduction on both sides in 2005 or 2006 and in June 2007 I was diagnosed with breast cancer. I didn't have any scans beforehand to see if anything was wrong - my breast consultant never ceases to be amazed that nobody thought to do this before my reduction. Anyway lumps can grow fast and I only realised something was wrong when I felt a huge lump in my armpit and my GP told me that I also had a large lump in my breast. It turned out to be IDC and HER2+++ and very aggressive hence the reason it grew so quickly. Oh yes, I also had widespread DCIS to mastectomy and lymph node removal for me.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed after a successful breast reduction nora_az LISAMG

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 08:15AM RebzAmy wrote: Hi LisaAMG I had no scans or anything before my breast reduction and I also had widespread DCIS when I was actually diagnosed in 2007. In terms of screening I was too young to start screening being only my 30s. It's very possible something was there when I had the reduction and this triggered the growth of the tumour or DCIS to become invasive - but who knows? I do have a family history, my dad's sister having been diagnosed around age 40 and then again a few years ago aged 55. My mum's sister was also diagnosed but at an older age - prob around 60. As a result of this, I also had preventative surgery recently by having the other unaffected side removed and rebuilt.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 02:54PM RebzAmy wrote: Hi Meaghan I just googled it for you and got the following: Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH) is a type of benign breast lesion that occurs as a single palpable mass or a dense region on a mammogram The masses observed in individuals with PASH are benign (non-cancerous) and require diagnosis only to distinguish them from cancerous (malignant) lesions.  It may be mistaken for angiosarcoma; however, the breast lesions caused by angiosarcoma are different than those seen in PASH The size of PASH lesions range from incidental microscopic findings to breast masses that are palpable or evident on a mammogram. Masses are usually large (5-6 cm in diameter), with reported diameters ranging from 1 to 12 cm.  The masses may grow over time PASH most commonly affects premenopausal women. The age range of people diagnosed with PASH is 14-67 years; however, most individuals are diagnosed in their late thirties or forties Surgical removal of the PASH lesions has been performed in some individuals.  A wide margin around the mass may be removed to prevent recurrence. Although PASH lesions often grow over time and may recur, they are neither associated with malignancy (cancer) nor considered to be premalignant (pre-cancerous).[1]  According to the medical text, CONN's Current Therapy 2007, approximately 7 percent of people experience a recurrence of PASH.[2]
Posts.Title: What is PASH? Meaghan alligans

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2013 12:48PM RebzAmy wrote: From what I understand, the rads are local treatment and treat the area with tumour plus surrounding areas just in case there are minute cells that have spread out a little.  If the cells have already spread (maybe minute cells have travelled around the body) rads will not treat these, chemo can as it treats the whole body. The rads are an important part of treatment as they can reach tissue and areas that surgery can't.  It wasn't particuarly tactful of the MO to say this however he/she was being brutally honest.  That said, nobody can say whose cancer will come back and whose won't whatever treatment you end up having.  I was given rads and it covered three different areas - this was the belts and braces of my treatment as my oncologist described it.
Posts.Title: RADS does it lower chances of distant mets too? rozem pupmom

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2015 02:13AM RebzAmy wrote: I did use the cold cap for the majority of my treatment and it didn't work and in the UK it's free. Towards the middle of treatment, so much hair had come out and the cold on my head was so painful, that I chose to stop using it in the end as it wasn't working. The cold was extremely uncomfortable and as my hair got thinner and thinner, it got worse and worse so I was pretty relieved in the end when I stopped using it. I then got a wig. I know that it can work for some people, but those people are very few.

So - both aunts had it and so did I but there's no faulty gene!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2012 09:51AM RebzAmy wrote: I was an egg donor for somebody - I went through the whole process three times for them which meant my body was flooded with hormones, firstly to do something called down regulating so that the person I was donating to was in synch with my body and my cycle, then I had to inject myself daily for 2-3 weeks (can't remember now) and finally the egg collection. It was a few months after the final collection I was diagnosed with breast cancer however mine was HER2+. In relation to the person I was donating to, this was a good thing because had it been hormonal cancer, they would have felt it may have been due to what I'd been through for them that caused this to happen but who knows! R
